text: William Cameron "Willie" McCool (September 23, 1961 â€“ February 1, 2003) (Cmdr, USN) was an American naval officer and aviator, test pilot, aeronautical engineer, and NASA astronaut. He was the pilot of Space Shuttle Columbia mission STS-107. He and the rest of the crew of STS-107 were killed when Columbia disintegrated during re-entry into the atmosphere.NASA. William C. McCool: NASA Astronaut: Biographical Data, Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center website, May 2004. Retrieved August 15, 2010. Note: this text, the work of a U.S. Government agency, is a work in the public domain.Kershaw, Sarah. Space Shuttle Widow Is Ready to Move on From Rituals of Loss, New York Times, December 5, 2007. Retrieved August 15, 2010. He was the youngest male member of the crew. McCool was posthumously awarded the Congressional Space Medal of Honor. ==References== Category:1961 births Category:2003 deaths Category:Aviation deaths Category:American astronauts Category:Engineers from California Category:Scientists from San Diego
title: William C. McCool
